heading: Deaths
txt: Ernst Chladni, German physicist and academic (b. 1756)

entities.title: Ernst Chladni
entities.description: Ernst Florens Friedrich Chladni was a German physicist and musician. His most important work, for which he is sometimes labeled as the father of acoustics, included research on vibrating plates and the calculation of the speed of sound for different gases. He also undertook pioneering work in the study of meteorites and is regarded by some as the father of meteoritics.

heading: Deaths
txt: François Carlo Antommarchi, French physician and author (b. 1780)

entities.title: François Carlo Antommarchi
entities.description: François Carlo Antommarchi was Napoleon's physician from 1818 to his death in 1821.

heading: Deaths
txt: Edward Bigge, English cleric, 1st Archdeacon of Lindisfarne (b. 1807)

entities.title: Edward Bigge
entities.description: Edward Thomas Bigge was an English cleric, the first appointee to the revived role of Archdeacon of Lindisfarne.

entities.title: Archdeacon of Lindisfarne
entities.description: The Archdeacon of Lindisfarne is a senior ecclesiastical officer in the diocese of Newcastle of the Church of England.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Braine, English soldier and explorer (b. 1814)

entities.title: William Braine
entities.description: William Braine was a British explorer. He served as a marine in the Royal Marines. From 1845 he was part of an expedition to find the Northwest Passage, but he died early in the trip and was buried on Beechey Island. His preserved body was exhumed in 1984, to try to determine the cause of death.

heading: Deaths
txt: Juliusz Słowacki, Polish-French poet and playwright (b. 1809)

entities.title: Juliusz Słowacki
entities.description: Juliusz Słowacki was a Polish Romantic poet. He is considered one of the "Three Bards" of Polish literature — a major figure in the Polish Romantic period, and the father of modern Polish drama. His works often feature elements of Slavic pagan traditions, Polish history, mysticism and orientalism. His style includes the employment of neologisms and irony. His primary genre was the drama, but he al

heading: Deaths
txt: Franz Berwald, Swedish composer and surgeon (b. 1796)

entities.title: Franz Berwald
entities.description: Franz Adolf Berwald was a Swedish Romantic composer. He made his living as an orthopedist and later as the manager of a saw mill and glass factory, and became more appreciated as a composer after his death than he had been in his lifetime.

heading: Deaths
txt: Felicita Vestvali, German actress and opera singer (b. 1831)

entities.title: Felicita Vestvali
entities.description: Felicita Vestvali, also known as Felicità von Vestvali, was an opera singer and actress famous in Europe and the United States.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jesse James, American criminal and outlaw (b. 1847)

entities.title: Jesse James
entities.description: Jesse Woodson James was an American outlaw, bank and train robber, guerrilla, and leader of the James–Younger Gang. Raised in the "Little Dixie" area of western Missouri, James and his family maintained strong Southern sympathies. He and his brother Frank James joined pro-Confederate guerrillas known as "bushwhackers" operating in Missouri and Kansas during the American Civil War. As followers of

heading: Deaths
txt: Johannes Brahms, German pianist and composer (b. 1833)

entities.title: Johannes Brahms
entities.description: Johannes Brahms was a German composer, pianist, and conductor of the Romantic period. Born in Hamburg into a Lutheran family, he spent much of his professional life in Vienna. He is sometimes grouped with Johann Sebastian Bach and Ludwig van Beethoven as one of the "Three Bs" of music, a comment originally made by the nineteenth-century conductor Hans von Bülow.

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard D'Oyly Carte, English composer and talent agent (b. 1844)

entities.title: Richard D'Oyly Carte
entities.description: Richard D'Oyly Carte was an English talent agent, theatrical impresario, composer and hotelier during the latter half of the Victorian era. He built two of London's theatres and a hotel empire, while also establishing an opera company that ran continuously for over a hundred years and a management agency representing some of the most important artists of the day.

heading: Deaths
txt: Esther Hobart Morris, American lawyer and judge (b. 1814)

entities.title: Esther Hobart Morris
entities.description: Esther Hobart Morris was the first woman justice of the peace in the United States. She began her tenure as justice in South Pass City, Wyoming, on February 14, 1870, serving a term of nearly 9 months. The Sweetwater County Board of County Commissioners appointed Morris as justice of the peace after the previous justice, R.S. Barr, resigned in protest of Wyoming Territory's passage of the women's

heading: Deaths
txt: Emma Albani, Canadian-English operatic soprano  (b. 1847)

entities.title: Emma Albani
entities.description: Dame Emma Albani, DBE was a leading opera soprano of the 19th century and early 20th century, and the first Canadian singer to become an international star. Her repertoire focused on the operas of Mozart, Rossini, Donizetti, Bellini and Wagner. She performed across Europe and North America.

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard Hauptmann, German-American murderer (b. 1899)

entities.title: Richard Hauptmann
entities.description: Bruno Richard Hauptmann was a German-born carpenter who was convicted of the abduction and murder of the 20-month-old son of aviator Charles Lindbergh and his wife Anne Morrow Lindbergh. The Lindbergh kidnapping became known as "The Crime of the Century". Hauptmann proclaimed his innocence to the end, but he was convicted of first degree murder and executed in 1936 in the electric chair at the New

heading: Deaths
txt: Tachiyama Mineemon, Japanese sumo wrestler, the 22nd Yokozuna (b. 1877)

entities.title: Tachiyama Mineemon
entities.description: Tachiyama Mineemon  was a Japanese professional sumo wrestler from Toyama City, Toyama Prefecture. He was the sport's 22nd yokozuna. He was well known for his extreme strength and skill. He won 99 out of 100 matches from 1909 to 1916, and also won eleven top division tournament championships.

entities.title: Yokozuna
entities.description: Makuuchi (幕内), or makunouchi (幕の内), is the top division of the six divisions of professional sumo. Its size is fixed at 42 wrestlers (rikishi), ordered into five ranks according to their ability as defined by their performance in previous tournaments.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pál Teleki, Hungarian academic and politician, 22nd Prime Minister of Hungary (b. 1879)

entities.title: Prime Minister of Hungary
entities.description: The prime minister of Hungary is the head of government in Hungary. The Prime Minister and the Cabinet are collectively accountable for their policies and actions to the Parliament, to their political party and ultimately to the electorate. The current holder of the office is Viktor Orbán, leader of the Fidesz – Hungarian Civic Alliance, who has served since 29 May 2010.

heading: Deaths
txt: Conrad Veidt, German actor, director, and producer (b. 1893)

entities.title: Conrad Veidt
entities.description: Hans Walter Conrad Veidt was a German actor best remembered for his roles in the films Different from the Others (1919), The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari (1920), and The Man Who Laughs (1928). After a successful career in German silent films, where he was one of the best-paid stars of UFA, he and his new Jewish wife Ilona Prager were forced to leave Germany in 1933 after the Nazis came to power. The co

heading: Deaths
txt: Masaharu Homma, Japanese general (b. 1887)

entities.title: Masaharu Homma
entities.description: Masaharu Homma  was a lieutenant general in the Imperial Japanese Army during World War II. Homma commanded the Japanese 14th Army, which invaded the Philippines and perpetrated the Bataan Death March. After the war, Homma was convicted of war crimes relating to the actions of troops under his direct command and executed by firing squad on April 3, 1946.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kurt Weill, German-American composer and pianist (b. 1900)

entities.title: Kurt Weill
entities.description: Kurt Julian Weill was a German composer, active from the 1920s in his native country, and in his later years in the United States. He was a leading composer for the stage who was best known for his fruitful collaborations with Bertolt Brecht. With Brecht, he developed productions such as his best-known work, The Threepenny Opera, which included the ballad "Mack the Knife". Weill held the ideal of

heading: Deaths
txt: Carter G. Woodson, American historian, author, and journalist, founded Black History Month (b. 1875)

entities.title: Black History Month
entities.description: Black History Month is an annual observance originating in the United States, where it is also known as African-American History Month. It has received official recognition from governments in the United States and Canada, and more recently has been observed in Ireland, the Netherlands, and the United Kingdom. It began as a way of remembering important people and events in the history of the Afric

heading: Deaths
txt: Henrik Visnapuu, Estonian poet and playwright (b. 1890)

entities.title: Henrik Visnapuu
entities.description: Henrik Visnapuu was a well-known Estonian poet and dramatist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Miina Sillanpää, Finnish minister and politician (b. 1866)

entities.title: Miina Sillanpää
entities.description: Miina Sillanpää was Finland's first female minister and a key figure in the workers' movement. In 2016, the Finnish government made 1 October an official flag day in honour of Sillanpää. She was involved in the preparation of Finland's first Municipal Homemaking Act.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ned Sparks, Canadian-American actor (b. 1883)

entities.title: Ned Sparks
entities.description: Ned Sparks was a Canadian-born character actor of the American stage and screen. Sparks was known for his deadpan expression and deep, gravelly voice.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jaan Kärner, Estonian poet and author (b. 1891)

entities.title: Jaan Kärner
entities.description: Jaan Kärner was an Estonian poet and writer. He is known especially for his nature poetry. Many of his poems were set to music by Estonian composers of choral music. Kärner also wrote numerous novels, plays, works of literary criticism, and scientific literature and historical treatises. He translated works from German and Russian, most notably the poems of Heinrich Heine into Estonian in 1934.

heading: Deaths
txt: Manolis Kalomiris, Greek composer and educator (b. 1883)

entities.title: Manolis Kalomiris
entities.description: Manolis Kalomiris was a Greek classical composer. He was the founder of the Greek National School of Music.

heading: Deaths
txt: Avigdor Hameiri, Israeli author (b. 1890)

entities.title: Avigdor Hameiri
entities.description: Avigdor Hameiri was an Israeli author.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Valachi, American gangster (b. 1904)

entities.title: Joseph Valachi
entities.description: Joseph Michael Valachi was an American gangster in the Genovese crime family who is notable as the first member of the Italian-American Mafia to, in 1963, acknowledge its existence publicly. He is credited with popularization of the term cosa nostra.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ferde Grofé, American pianist and composer (b. 1892)

entities.title: Ferde Grofé
entities.description: Ferdinand Rudolph von Grofé, known as Ferde Grofé was an American composer, arranger, pianist and instrumentalist. He is best known for his 1931 five-movement tone poem, Grand Canyon Suite.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mary Ure, Scottish-English actress (b. 1933)

entities.title: Mary Ure
entities.description: Eileen Mary Ure was a British stage and film actress. She was the second Scottish-born actress to be nominated for an Academy Award, for her role in the 1960 film Sons and Lovers.

heading: Deaths
txt: David M. Dennison, American physicist and academic (b. 1900)

entities.title: David M. Dennison
entities.description: David Mathias Dennison was an American physicist who made contributions to quantum mechanics, spectroscopy, and the physics of molecular structure.

heading: Deaths
txt: Claude-Henri Grignon, Canadian journalist and politician (b. 1894)

heading: Deaths
txt: Ray Noble, English bandleader, composer, and actor (b. 1903)

entities.title: Ray Noble
entities.description: Raymond Stanley Noble was an English bandleader, composer, arranger, radio comedian, and actor. Noble wrote both lyrics and music for many popular songs during the British dance band era, known as the "Golden Age of British music", notably for his longtime friend and associate Al Bowlly, including "Love Is the Sweetest Thing", "Cherokee", "The Touch of Your Lips", "I Hadn't Anyone Till You", and h

heading: Deaths
txt: Winston Sharples, American composer (b. 1909)

heading: Deaths
txt: Juan Trippe, American businessman, founded Pan American World Airways (b. 1899)

entities.title: Juan Trippe
entities.description: Juan Terry Trippe was an American commercial aviation pioneer, entrepreneur and the founder of Pan American World Airways, one of the iconic airlines of the 20th century. He was instrumental in numerous revolutionary advances in airline history, including the development and production of the Boeing 314 Clipper, which opened trans-Pacific airline travel, the Boeing Stratoliner which helped to pion

entities.title: Pan American World Airways
entities.description: Pan American World Airways, originally founded as Pan American Airways and commonly known as Pan Am, was the principal and largest international air carrier and unofficial overseas flag carrier of the United States from 1927 until the airline's collapse on December 4, 1991. Pan Am is credited for many innovations that shaped the international airline industry, including the widespread use of jet a

heading: Deaths
txt: Warren Oates, American actor (b. 1928)

entities.title: Warren Oates
entities.description: Warren Mercer Oates was an American actor best known for his performances in several films directed by Sam Peckinpah, including The Wild Bunch (1969) and Bring Me the Head of Alfredo Garcia (1974). Another of his most acclaimed performances was as officer Sam Wood in In the Heat of the Night (1967). Oates starred in numerous films during the early 1970s that have since achieved cult status, such a

heading: Deaths
txt: Jimmy Bloomfield, English footballer and manager (b. 1934)

entities.title: Jimmy Bloomfield
entities.description: James Henry Bloomfield was an English football player and manager. He made nearly 500 appearances in the Football League, including more than 300 in the First Division with Arsenal, Birmingham City and West Ham United. He was capped by England at under-23 level. He then spent 13 years in management with Orient and Leicester City.

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter Pears, English tenor and educator (b. 1910)

entities.title: Peter Pears
entities.description: Sir Peter Neville Luard Pears was an English tenor. His career was closely associated with the composer Benjamin Britten, his personal and professional partner for nearly forty years.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tom Sestak, American football player (b. 1936)

entities.title: Tom Sestak
entities.description: Thomas Joseph Sestak was an American football defensive lineman who played for the Buffalo Bills of the American Football League (AFL).

heading: Deaths
txt: Milton Caniff, American cartoonist (b. 1907)

entities.title: Milton Caniff
entities.description: Milton Arthur Paul "Milt" Caniff was an American cartoonist famous for the Terry and the Pirates and Steve Canyon comic strips.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sarah Vaughan, American singer (b. 1924)

entities.title: Sarah Vaughan
entities.description: Sarah Lois Vaughan was an American jazz singer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Goren, American bridge player and author (b. 1901)

entities.title: Charles Goren
entities.description: Charles Henry Goren was an American bridge player and writer who significantly developed and popularized the game. He was the leading American bridge personality in the 1950s and 1960s – or 1940s and 1950s, as "Mr. Bridge" – as Ely Culbertson had been in the 1930s. Culbertson, Goren, and Harold Vanderbilt were the three people named when The Bridge World inaugurated a bridge "hall of fame" in 1964

heading: Deaths
txt: Graham Greene, English novelist, playwright, and critic (b. 1904)

heading: Deaths
txt: Pinky Lee, American television host (b. 1907)

entities.title: Pinky Lee
entities.description: Pincus Leff, better known as Pinky Lee, was an American burlesque comic and host of the children's television program The Pinky Lee Show in the early 1950s.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frank Wells, American businessman (b. 1932)

entities.title: Frank Wells
entities.description: Franklin G. Wells was an American businessman who served as president of The Walt Disney Company from 1984 until his death in 1994.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alfred J. Billes, Canadian businessman, co-founded Canadian Tire (b. 1902)

entities.title: Alfred J. Billes
entities.description: Alfred Jackson Billes, CM was a Canadian businessman and co-founder of Canadian Tire.

entities.title: Canadian Tire
entities.description: Canadian Tire Corporation Limited is a Canadian retail company which operates in the automotive, hardware, sports, leisure and housewares sectors. Its Canadian operations include: Canadian Tire, Mark's, FGL Sports, PartSource, and the Canadian operations of Party City. Canadian Tire acquired the Norwegian clothing and textile company Helly Hansen from the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan in 2015.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ron Brown, American captain and politician, 30th United States Secretary of Commerce (b. 1941)

entities.title: Ron Brown
entities.description: Ronald Harmon Brown was an American politician. He served as the United States Secretary of Commerce during the first term of President Bill Clinton. Prior to this he was chairman of the Democratic National Committee (DNC). He was the first African American to hold these positions. He was killed, along with 34 others in a 1996 plane crash in Croatia.

entities.title: United States Secretary of Commerce
entities.description: The United States secretary of commerce (SecCom) is the head of the United States Department of Commerce. The secretary serves as the principal advisor to the president of the United States on all matters relating to commerce. The secretary reports directly to the president and is a statutory member of Cabinet of the United States. The secretary is appointed by the president, with the advice and c

heading: Deaths
txt: Mary Cartwright, English mathematician and academic (b. 1900)

entities.title: Mary Cartwright
entities.description: Dame Mary Lucy Cartwright, was a British mathematician. She was one of the pioneers of what would later become known as chaos theory. Along with J. E. Littlewood, Cartwright saw many solutions to a problem which would later be seen as an example of the butterfly effect.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lionel Bart, English composer (b. 1930)

entities.title: Lionel Bart
entities.description: Lionel Bart was a British writer and composer of pop music and musicals. He wrote Tommy Steele's "Rock with the Caveman" and was the sole creator of the musical Oliver! (1960). With Oliver! and his work alongside theatre director Joan Littlewood at Theatre Royal, Stratford East, he played an instrumental role in the 1960s birth of the British musical theatre scene after an era when American musica

heading: Deaths
txt: Geoffrey Walsh, Canadian general (b. 1909)

heading: Deaths
txt: Terence McKenna, American botanist and philosopher (b. 1946)

entities.title: Terence McKenna
entities.description: Terence Kemp McKenna was an American ethnobotanist and mystic who advocated for the responsible use of naturally occurring psychedelic plants. He spoke and wrote about a variety of subjects, including psychedelic drugs, plant-based entheogens, shamanism, metaphysics, alchemy, language, philosophy, culture, technology, environmentalism, and the theoretical origins of human consciousness. He was cal

heading: Deaths
txt: Dina Abramowicz, Librarian and YIVO and Yiddish language expert (b. 1909)

heading: Deaths
txt: François Gérin, Canadian lawyer and politician (b. 1944)

entities.title: François Gérin
entities.description: François Gérin was a member of the House of Commons of Canada. He was a lawyer by career.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nina Wang, Chinese businesswoman (b. 1937)

entities.title: Nina Wang
entities.description: Nina Wang, born Kung Yu Sum 29 September 1937 – 3 April 2007) was Asia's richest woman, with an estimated net worth of US$4.2 billion at the time of her death. She was the widow of Hong Kong chemical magnate Teddy Wang, who was kidnapped and disappeared in 1990.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hrvoje Ćustić, Croatian footballer (b. 1983)

entities.title: Hrvoje Ćustić
entities.description: Hrvoje Ćustić was a Croatian footballer who played as a midfielder.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mingote, Spanish cartoonist and journalist (b. 1919)

entities.title: Mingote
entities.description: Ángel Antonio Mingote Barrachina, 1st Marquis of Daroca, also simply known as Mingote, was a Spanish cartoonist, writer and journalist. He drew a daily cartoon in ABC since 1953 until his death in 2012.

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard Descoings, French civil servant (b. 1958)

heading: Deaths
txt: Govind Narain, Indian politician, 8th Governor of Karnataka (b. 1917)

entities.title: List of Governors of Karnataka
entities.description: The Governor of Karnataka is the constitutional head of the south Indian state of Karnataka. The governor is appointed by the President of India for a term of five years, and holds office at the President's pleasure. The governor is de jure head of the Government of Karnataka; all its executive actions are taken in the governor's name. However, the governor must act on the advice of the popularly

heading: Deaths
txt: Chief Jay Strongbow, American wrestler (b. 1928)

heading: Deaths
txt: José María Zárraga, Spanish footballer and manager (b. 1930)

heading: Deaths
txt: Mariví Bilbao, Spanish actress (b. 1930)

entities.title: Mariví Bilbao
entities.description: María Victoria Bilau-Goyoaga Álvarez better known by her stage name Mariví Bilbao was a Spanish actress, especially famous for her roles as Marisa Benito in Aquí no hay quien viva and Izaskun Sagastume in La que se avecina.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, German-American author and screenwriter (b. 1927)

heading: Deaths
txt: Régine Deforges, French author, playwright, and director (b. 1935)

entities.title: Régine Deforges
entities.description: Régine Deforges was a French author, editor, director, and playwright. Her book La Bicyclette bleue was the most popular book in France in 2000 and it was known by some to be offensive and to others for its plagiarism, neither of which was proved.

heading: Deaths
txt: Fred Kida, American illustrator (b. 1920)

txt: Prince Michael of Prussia (b. 1940)

heading: Deaths
txt: Jovan Pavlović, Serbian metropolitan (b. 1936)

heading: Deaths
txt: Arthur "Guitar Boogie" Smith, American guitarist, fiddler, and composer (b. 1921)

heading: Deaths
txt: Sarah Brady, American activist and author (b. 1942)

entities.title: Sarah Brady
entities.description: Sarah Jane Brady was a prominent advocate for gun control in the United States. Her husband, James Brady, was press secretary to U.S. president Ronald Reagan and was left permanently disabled as a result of an assassination attempt on Reagan.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bob Burns, American drummer and songwriter (b. 1950)

heading: Deaths
txt: Shmuel Wosner, Austrian-Israeli rabbi and author  (b. 1913)

heading: Deaths
txt: Cesare Maldini, Italian footballer and manager (b. 1932)

entities.title: Cesare Maldini
entities.description: Cesare Maldini was an Italian professional football manager and player, who played as a defender.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joe Medicine Crow, American anthropologist, historian, and author (b. 1913)

heading: Deaths
txt: Koji Wada, Japanese singer and songwriter (b. 1974)

heading: Deaths
txt: Kishori Amonkar, Indian classical vocalist (b. 1931)

entities.title: Kishori Amonkar
entities.description: Kishori Ravindra Amonkar was a leading Indian classical vocalist, belonging to the Jaipur gharana, or a community of musicians sharing a distinctive musical style.

heading: Deaths
txt: Stan Stephens, Canadian-American politician, 20th Governor of Montana (b. 1929)

entities.title: Stan Stephens
entities.description: Stanley Graham Stephens was a Canadian-American politician, journalist, and broadcaster who served as the 20th Governor of Montana from 1989 until 1993.

entities.title: Governor of Montana
entities.description: The Governor of Montana is the head of the executive branch of Montana's state government and the commander-in-chief of the state's military forces. The governor has a duty to enforce state laws, the power to either approve or veto bills passed by the Montana State Legislature, to convene the legislature at any time, and to grant pardons and reprieves.
